DataElement.preferredDefinition: Classification category that describes the likelihood that germline variant is causally related to a heritable disease.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any mutation that appears in the gametes and which will therefore be transmitted to the progeny with some frequency._The likelihood of an entity to produce pathologic changes or disease.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Any detectable and heritable alteration in the lineage of germ cells. Mutations in these cells (i.e., "generative" cells ancestral to the gametes) are transmitted to progeny while those in somatic cells are not.

Concepts.definition: Any mutation that appears in the gametes and which will therefore be transmitted to the progeny with some frequency.

Property.preferredDefinition: The likelihood of an entity to produce pathologic changes or disease.

Concepts.definition: The likelihood of an entity to produce pathologic changes or disease.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position (locus) on a particular chromosome, is capable of reproducing itself exactly at each cell division, and directs the formation of a protein or other product. The gene as a functional unit consists of a discrete segment of a giant DNA molecule containing the purine (adenine and guanine) and pyrimidine (cytosine and thymine) bases in the ordered and correct sequence that encodes a specific functional product (i.e., a protein or RNA molecule).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for NCI-INC0454031 - potential new CDE and PVs request by Liz 2/4/20

ValueDomain.preferredName: ACMG Classification of Genomic Variant Pathogenicity Category
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A five-tiered classification from the American College of Medical Genetics designed to describe the likelihood that a genomic sequence variant is causative of an inherited disease._A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A genetic variant that is known to not contribute to the development of a disease.

Concepts.definition: A genetic variant that is known to not contribute to the development of a disease.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A genetic variant that is not expected to contribute to the development of a disease, but the scientific evidence may be insufficient to prove this conclusively.

Concepts.definition: A genetic variant that is not expected to contribute to the development of a disease, but the scientific evidence may be insufficient to prove this conclusively.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An indication that there is not enough information to support a more definitive classification of the pathogenicity of a genetic variant.

Concepts.definition: An indication that there is not enough information to support a more definitive classification of the pathogenicity of a genetic variant.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An ad hoc category that describes genetic variants with 90% or greater certainty of contributing to the development of a disease.

Concepts.definition: An ad hoc category that describes genetic variants with 90% or greater certainty of contributing to the development of a disease.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A genetic variant that is known to have a high likelihood (greater than 90% certainty) to contribute to the development of a disease.

Concepts.definition: A genetic variant that is known to have a high likelihood (greater than 90% certainty) to contribute to the development of a disease.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A genetic variant that is known to directly contribute to the development of disease.

Concepts.definition: A genetic variant that is known to directly contribute to the development of disease.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position (locus) on a particular chromosome, is capable of reproducing itself exactly at each cell division, and directs the formation of a protein or other product. The gene as a functional unit consists of a discrete segment of a giant DNA molecule containing the purine (adenine and guanine) and pyrimidine (cytosine and thymine) bases in the ordered and correct sequence that encodes a specific functional product (i.e., a protein or RNA molecule).

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: ACMG Classification of Genomic Variant Pathogenicity Category
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A five-tiered classification from the American College of Medical Genetics designed to describe the likelihood that a genomic sequence variant is causative of an inherited disease.:A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

Concepts.longName: ACMG Classification of Genomic Variant Pathogenicity
Concepts.definition: A five-tiered classification from the American College of Medical Genetics designed to describe the likelihood that a genomic sequence variant is causative of an inherited disease.
A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.
